page.title: 08History of Wallop
page.content: If any region deserves to be called the cradle of England, this must surely be it. From the famous Iron Age hill settlement of Danebury to the site of the mysterious Dark Age battle of Guoloppum in AD436 on the Wallop Brook, it is part of the very fabric of Early English History. In 1918 a hoard of Bronze Age axes, almost certainly a travelling smith's stock, were discovered to the north east of Nether Wallop. Between the two World Wars, a Neolithic Longbarrow about 500m NE of our school was destroyed to make way for the modern airfield and also introducing the modern name of Middle Wallop.In the centre of the region the name Bustards Corner is the only reminder of the beautiful birds,now extinct,which once flew over Hampshire
